Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: A binding client contract cannot be finalized until they provide precise effort estimates
Story: I stared at my phone, the group chat with my step-siblings lighting up with plans for the holiday trip. My stepmom’s message was clear: “It would mean a lot if you could be there this year.” I knew how important it was to show up, to be part of the family, especially since I’d always felt a bit like an outsider. But my laptop screen glared back at me, the project timeline blinking in my inbox. My manager’s email was just as urgent: “We need your estimates by tomorrow morning. The client’s waiting to sign.” I could almost hear the tension in his words, the weight of the contract hanging on my calculations. My mind raced, torn between the warmth of family expectations and the cold precision of engineering demands. I wanted to be present for my step-siblings, to finally feel like I belonged, but I also knew the team was counting on me. My chest tightened as I tried to figure out how to be in two places at once, feeling the pressure build with every passing minute.
